deck.name: Land Navigation
deck.description: TC 3-25.26 - Comprehensive coverage of map reading, terrain features, grid coordinates, compass, and navigation techniques

cards.front: What is the standard military map scale for tactical operations?
On a 1:50,000 map, how many meters is one grid square?
cards.back:
1,000 meters × 1,000 meters.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: On a 1:50,000 map, how many inches equals one mile?
cards.back:
Approximately 1.27 inches.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-2)

cards.front: What does BLACK represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Man-made features (buildings, roads, boundaries).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does BLUE represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Water features (lakes, rivers, streams, swamps).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does BROWN represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Contour lines and elevation.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does GREEN represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Vegetation (woods, orchards, vineyards).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What does RED represent on a military map?
cards.back:
Major roads, built-up areas, special features.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-8)

cards.front: What is a contour line?
cards.back:
A line connecting points of equal elevation.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-2)

cards.front: What is a contour interval?
cards.back:
The vertical distance between adjacent contour lines.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-3)

cards.front: Where do you find the contour interval on a map?
cards.back:
In the marginal information at the bottom of the map.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-3)

cards.front: What is an index contour line?
cards.back:
A heavier contour line (every fifth line) with elevation printed on it.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-4)

cards.front: What does steep terrain look like on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines close together.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-6)

cards.front: What does gentle terrain look like on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines far apart.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-6)

cards.front: How do you identify a HILL on a map?
cards.back:
Closed contour circles with elevation increasing toward center.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a VALLEY on a map?
cards.back:
Contours form U/V pointing UPHILL (toward higher ground).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a RIDGE on a map?
cards.back:
Contours form U/V pointing DOWNHILL (toward lower ground).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a SADDLE on a map?
cards.back:
Low point between two higher elevations (hourglass shape).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How do you identify a DEPRESSION on a map?
cards.back:
Closed contours with tick marks pointing INWARD (toward lower center).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: What is a DRAW?
cards.back:
A less developed valley, often the beginning of a stream.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What is a SPUR?
cards.back:
A short ridge extending from higher ground.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What is a CLIFF on a map?
cards.back:
Contour lines very close together or touching.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What is a CUT on a map?
cards.back:
Man-made feature cutting through terrain (road through a hill).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-10)

cards.front: What is a FILL on a map?
cards.back:
Man-made elevated terrain (embankment, berm).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-10)

cards.front: How many major terrain features are there?
cards.back:
Five: Hill, Ridge, Valley, Saddle, Depression.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-8)

cards.front: How many minor terrain features are there?
cards.back:
Three: Draw, Spur, Cliff.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: How many supplementary terrain features are there?
cards.back:
Two: Cut, Fill.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-10)

cards.front: What is the rule for reading grid coordinates?
cards.back:
Read RIGHT then UP (easting before northing).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-5)

cards.front: What accuracy does a 4-digit grid provide?
cards.back:
Within 1,000 meters.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What accuracy does a 6-digit grid provide?
cards.back:
Within 100 meters.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What accuracy does an 8-digit grid provide?
cards.back:
Within 10 meters.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What accuracy does a 10-digit grid provide?
cards.back:
Within 1 meter.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-6)

cards.front: What is an easting?
cards.back:
The first half of a grid coordinate (horizontal position, read RIGHT).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-5)

cards.front: What is a northing?
cards.back:
The second half of a grid coordinate (vertical position, read UP).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-5)

cards.front: What is MGRS?
cards.back:
Military Grid Reference System - standard military grid system.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-2)

cards.front: What is a Grid Zone Designator?
cards.back:
The zone number and letter identifying a 6° × 8° area (e.g., 18S).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: What is the 100,000-meter square identifier?
cards.back:
Two letters identifying a 100km × 100km area within a zone (e.g., UJ).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: What are the three norths?
cards.back:
True North, Grid North, and Magnetic North.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-2)

cards.front: What is True North?
cards.back:
Direction to the geographic North Pole (star symbol on map).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-2)

cards.front: What is Grid North?
cards.back:
Direction of the vertical grid lines on a map (GN symbol).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-2)

cards.front: What is Magnetic North?
cards.back:
Direction a compass needle points (half-arrow symbol).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-2)

cards.front: What is declination?
cards.back:
The angular difference between magnetic north and true north.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-3)

cards.front: What is the G-M angle?
cards.back:
The angular difference between grid north and magnetic north.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-4)

cards.front: Convert magnetic to grid azimuth when G-M angle is EAST.
cards.back:
SUBTRACT the G-M angle.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: Convert magnetic to grid azimuth when G-M angle is WEST.
cards.back:
ADD the G-M angle.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: What is the declination memory aid?
cards.back:
"East is Least, West is Best" (subtract for east, add for west).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-5)

cards.front: What is an azimuth?
cards.back:
A horizontal angle measured clockwise from north (0-360° or 0-6400 mils).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: How do you calculate a back azimuth?
cards.back:
If azimuth <180°: ADD 180. If ≥180°: SUBTRACT 180.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What is 90° in mils?
cards.back:
1,600 mils.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: What is 180° in mils?
cards.back:
3,200 mils.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: What is 270° in mils?
cards.back:
4,800 mils.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: How many mils in a circle?
cards.back:
6,400 mils.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 6, para 6-1)

cards.front: What are the three methods of holding a compass?
cards.back:
Compass-to-Cheek, Center-Hold, and Compass-to-Map.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 9, para 9-3)

cards.front: What is the compass-to-cheek method used for?
cards.back:
Shooting precise azimuths to distant objects.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 9, para 9-4)

cards.front: What is the center-hold method used for?
cards.back:
Quick, less precise readings or following an azimuth while moving.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 9, para 9-5)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the bezel ring?
cards.back:
To set and hold a desired azimuth for navigation.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 9, para 9-2)

cards.front: How many clicks does one bezel ring rotation equal?
cards.back:
120 clicks (each click = 3 degrees).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 9, para 9-2)

cards.front: What is a pace count?
cards.back:
The number of double-steps to travel 100 meters.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-4)

cards.front: How do you adjust pace count for uphill terrain?
cards.back:
Add paces (steps are shorter going uphill).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-5)

cards.front: How do you adjust pace count for soft terrain (sand/snow)?
cards.back:
Add paces (steps are shorter in soft terrain).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-5)

cards.front: What is dead reckoning?
cards.back:
Navigation using azimuth and distance from a known point.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-2)

cards.front: What is terrain association?
cards.back:
Navigation by comparing map features to ground features.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-3)

cards.front: What is intersection?
cards.back:
Locating an unknown point by sighting from two known positions.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 7, para 7-2)

cards.front: What is resection?
cards.back:
Determining your location by sighting to two or more known points.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 7, para 7-3)

cards.front: How many known points minimum for resection?
cards.back:
Two (three is preferred for accuracy).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 7, para 7-3)

cards.front: What is a handrail in navigation?
cards.back:
A linear feature paralleling your route that helps guide movement.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-8)

cards.front: What is a catching feature?
cards.back:
An obvious feature beyond your objective that indicates you've gone too far.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-9)

cards.front: What is a steering mark?
cards.back:
A distant object on your azimuth used to maintain direction.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-10)

cards.front: What is deliberate offset?
cards.back:
Intentionally navigating left or right of the objective to know which way to turn.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-11)

cards.front: What is an attack point?
cards.back:
An easy-to-find feature near your objective used as a final reference.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-12)

cards.front: What is a checkpoint?
cards.back:
A readily identifiable feature used to verify your position along a route.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-13)

cards.front: What is a control point?
cards.back:
A point where you change direction or receive instructions.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 10, para 10-14)

cards.front: What does OAKOC stand for?
cards.back:
Observation, Avenues of approach, Key terrain, Obstacles, Cover and concealment.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 11, para 11-2)

cards.front: What is key terrain?
cards.back:
Any location that gives a marked advantage to whoever controls it.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 11, para 11-5)

cards.front: What is an avenue of approach?
cards.back:
A route that allows a force to reach a key area or objective.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 11, para 11-4)

cards.front: What information is found in the map's marginal data?
cards.back:
Sheet name, scale, contour interval, grid info, declination diagram, legend.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-10)

cards.front: What is a protractor used for in land navigation?
cards.back:
Measuring and plotting azimuths and grid coordinates on a map.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 5, para 5-2)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the map's legend?
cards.back:
To explain the symbols used on the map.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-12)

cards.front: What is a benchmark on a map?
cards.back:
A point of known elevation, marked with "BM" and elevation value.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: What is a spot elevation on a map?
cards.back:
A point showing exact elevation, marked with "×" and number.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-12)

cards.front: How do you orient a map using terrain association?
cards.back:
Align map features with corresponding ground features.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 8, para 8-2)

cards.front: How do you orient a map using a compass?
cards.back:
Align the map's grid lines with magnetic north (apply G-M angle).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 8, para 8-3)

cards.front: What does UTM stand for?
cards.back:
Universal Transverse Mercator (a grid system).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 4, para 4-2)

cards.front: What type of map projection do military maps use?
cards.back:
Transverse Mercator projection.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-4)

cards.front: What is the purpose of a scale bar on a map?
cards.back:
To measure actual ground distance on the map.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-14)

cards.front: How do you measure distance using a paper strip?
cards.back:
Mark start and end on paper edge, align with scale bar to read distance.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 2, para 2-15)

cards.front: What is night navigation's biggest challenge?
cards.back:
Limited visibility requires more reliance on compass and pace count.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 12, para 12-2)

cards.front: How do you use the North Star for navigation?
cards.back:
The North Star (Polaris) is always within 1° of true north.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 12, para 12-8)

cards.front: How do you find the North Star?
cards.back:
Follow the Big Dipper's "pointer stars" (front of the cup) approximately 5× the distance.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 12, para 12-8)

cards.front: What is a supplementary contour line?
cards.back:
A dashed line at half the normal interval used in flat terrain.

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What shape do contour lines make when crossing a stream?
cards.back:
V-shape pointing UPSTREAM (toward higher elevation).

(Source: TC 3-25.26, Ch 3, para 3-7)
